data.title: RUSSIAN ARMY HALTS PANZER PENETRATION AT KURSK
data.meta_description: LONDON, Tuesday.--Besides holding firmly all attacks at the northern end of the Kursk salient, 250 miles south-west of Moscow, the Russians have halted Panzer penetration ...
data.text:
TI/TOSCOW 'Radio admits, however, .

-"-1- there is a serious threat to the"

Russian left flank on the Byelgorod

front, where fierce tank battles are

raging. , ,

Moscow claims that in the fight

ing, now in its ninth day, the

Nazis have lost more than 2500 tanks

and nearly 1100 planes.

Berlin Radio says that since July 5,

when the offensive opened, 28,000

Russians as well as 1600 tanks have

been captured.

In the sector north-west of Kursk

I yesterday the enemy launched fur

ther attacks with huge infantry

forces, supported by tanks, but

rthese failed. ' .

Stormovik i tank-buster) pianes, m

a spectacular swoop over the

German lines, blasted a division pre

paring to attack, crippling many

vehicles. â€ž

Halted In Wedge

The Daily Mirror's military corres

pondent says that the second week

of the battle finds the Germans still

trving to exploit the wedge north of

Byelgorod. Fortunately the Russians

have been able to hold up the Nazis

before the wedge is wide enough to

allow the troops to pour in. The

battle therefore remains more or less

static.

He declares that the Germans , ex

pected that lightning attacks would

enable them to straighten the line,

saving 400 miles, and allow Hitler to

release more divisions to meet the

Allied invasion forces.

For the first time Hitler has met

an army employing frustration tac

tics, declares the writer. Field-

Marshal von Kluge is finding his

master in Marshal Timoshenko, who

has long" prepared for this kind of

attack

The Nazis have sent in waves of

80 to 90 Messerschmitts and Focke-

wulfs, believing they had to keep the

Soviet fighters separated from the

Nazi bombers, but the fighters made

a wide detour, attacking the bombers

where least expected.

Soviet Air Mastery

This is upsetting the . Luftwaffe's

plans and giving the Soviet air mas

tery.

Red Air Force planes thus are

able to concentrate against tanks

because of the narrowness of the

wedge. This, to; a large extent, ex

plains the high number of Panzer

units destroyed.

The correspondent adds that the

Russians are introducing their newest

tank, the 52-ton Kutusov, demonstrat

ing that the Soviet feels it has cleaned

up the situation sufficiently to enable

them to take the initiative.

Last night's . Russian communique

savs that stubborn fighting is pro

ceeding. It claims that 122 enemy

tanks were destroyed and- 17 planes

shot down yesterday.
